prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spiral structures in the transition disk of HD 135344B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal targets the transition disk of HD 135344B. The fact that this protoplanetary disk has both a dust gap and spirals makes the presence of planet(s) plausible. Cycle 2 resolutions will build a coherent picture of the gas dynamics in the disk, by sampling the density and velocity fields, and put new constrains on the origin of the spirals (planet, G.I. or other). The different objectives within this science goal are: 1) the detection of spiral arms in band 6 12CO J=2-1 at angular resolution of 0.18 arcsec; 2) estimate opacity and gas mass in- and outside of the gap thanks to the 13CO isotopologue; 3) characterize the 1.3mm continuum at unprecedented resolution and correlate the asymmetric horseshoe to the spirals.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Peak continuum flux density and peak line flux density are computed from observations of Lyo et al 2011. They found an integrated flux of 141 mJy for the continuum (with a beam of 0.88''x 0.33'') and a peak intensity in CO 2-1 of 1.08 Jy/beam (with a beam of 1.16''x 0.65''). We used a value of 1'' for the radius of the disk, as suggested by the intensity maps of Lyo et al 2011, to compute the continuum peak flux value.
Our SNR of ~12 on the peak line flux density results from compromise with the time of observation and from the fact that HD 135344B is likely slightly older than the 2 other targets, hence with less gas remaining. It has to be noted that one of our spiral in HD 142527 was detected just above the 3 sigma level in the peak intensity map, so that we estimate that an SNR above 10 sigma is sufficient to put useful constraints.
Although we do not need a spectral resolution of 61kHz for our science goal, we do not have other choice if we want to observe at the same time CO 2-1 and 13CO 2-1 transitions in view of the separation of 10.14GHz between both lines. Choosing a spectral resolution of 122 kHz or larger (234 MHz width) would imply the lines to overtake the limit of the basebands. We will then average channels to obtain bins of 0.2 km/s width, hence increasing the SNR. This resolution was sufficient to detect the three spiral arms in HD 142527.
The mid-frequency of the continuum range was chosen to avoid the slight dips in atmospheric transmission at 231.3GHz and 234 GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spirals in the transition disk of MWC 758
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal targets the transition disk of MWC 758. The fact that this protoplanetary disk has both a dust gap and spirals makes the presence of planet(s) plausible. Cycle 2 resolutions will build a coherent picture of the gas dynamics in the disk, by sampling the density and velocity fields, and put new constrains on the origin of the spirals (planet, G.I. or other). The different objectives within this science goal are: 1) the detection of spiral arms in band 6 12CO J=2-1 at angular resolution of 0.18 arcsec; 2) estimate opacity and gas mass in- and outside of the gap thanks to the 13CO isotopologue; 3) characterize the 1.3mm continuum at unprecedented resolution and correlate the asymmetric continuum to the spirals.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Peak 1.3mm-continuum flux density is computed from observations of Chapillon et al 2008, who found an integrated flux of 56 mJy. We used a value of ~1'' for the radius of the disk, as suggested by their intensity maps. MWC 758 iss likely the youngest of the stars of this sample, and has probably higher gas to dust ratio, so that it leads to the lowest (but still totally acceptable) SNR (~55) for the continuum.
For the peak line flux density, we rather base on Isella et al 2010, who observed MWC 758 in CO 3-2 at higher angular resolution than Chapillon et al. They found an integrated flux in CO 3-2 of 4.2 Jy. We used a value of ~0.8'' for the radius of the disk, as suggested by their intensity maps, in order to compute our peak flux density of the CO 2-1 line.
Although we do not need a spectral resolution of 61kHz for our science goal, we do not have other choice if we want to observe at the same time CO 2-1 and 13CO 2-1 transitions in view of the separation of 10.14GHz between both lines. Choosing a spectral resolution of 122 kHz or larger (234 MHz width) would imply the lines to overtake the limit of the basebands. We will then average channels to obtain bins of 0.2 km/s width, hence increasing the SNR. This resolution was sufficient to detect the three spiral arms in HD 142527.
The mid-frequency of the continuum range was chosen to avoid the slight dips in atmospheric transmission at 231.3GHz and 234 GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spiral structures in the transition disk of HD 100546
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal targets the transition disk of HD 100546. The fact that this protoplanetary disk has both a dust gap and spirals makes the presence of planet(s) plausible. Cycle 2 resolutions will build a coherent picture of the gas dynamics in the disk, by sampling the density and velocity fields, and put new constrains on the origin of the spirals (planet, G.I. or other). The different objectives within this science goal are: 1) the detection of spiral arms in band 6 12CO J=2-1 at angular resolution of 0.18 arcsec; 2) estimate opacity and gas mass in- and outside of the gap thanks to the 13CO isotopologue; 3) characterize the 1.3mm continuum for the first time.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1.3mm continuum and CO J=2-1 were never observed on this source. Nevertheless, Panic et al 2010 observed the CO J=3-2 line (unresolved). They found an integrated flux of ~30 Jy. Considering a source size of 3 arcsec in radius (), we obtain a value of ~ 108 mJy/beam for the line intensity at a beam size of 0.18''. This has to be considered a lower limit as CO J=2-1 is expected to be brighter than CO 3-2.
For the peak intensity of the continuum, we took an average value of 4 mJy/beam based on the values found for HD 135344B and MWC 758.
The mid-frequency of the continuum range was chosen to avoid the slight dips in atmospheric transmission at 231.3GHz and 234 GHz.
Although we do not need a spectral resolution of 61kHz for our science goal, we do not have other choice if we want to observe at the same time CO 2-1 and 13CO 2-1 transitions in view of the separation of 10.14GHz between both lines. Choosing a spectral resolution of 122 kHz or larger (234 MHz width) would imply the lines to overtake the limit of the basebands. We will then average channels to obtain bins of 0.2 km/s width, hence increasing the SNR. This resolution was sufficient to detect the three spiral arms in HD 142527.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Large-scale spiral structures in the transition disk of HD 100546
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal targets the transition disk of HD 100546. The fact that this protoplanetary disk has both a dust gap and spirals makes the presence of planet(s) plausible. Cycle 2 resolutions will build a coherent picture of the gas dynamics in the disk, by sampling the density and velocity fields, and put new constrains on the origin of the spirals (planet, G.I. or other). The different objectives within this science goal are the same as the third one. However, as it is known that the disk is very extended (e.g. Grady et al. 2001, Ardila et al. 2007), we propose a second observation of the same disk at different angular resolution, in order to characterize the largest outer structures.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1.3mm continuum and CO J=2-1 were never observed on this source. Nevertheless, Panic et al 2010 observed the CO J=3-2 line (unresolved). They found an integrated flux of ~30 Jy. Considering a source size of 3 arcsec in radius (), we obtain a value of ~ 408 mJy/beam for the line intensity at a beam size of 0.35''. This has to be considered a lower limit as CO J=2-1 is expected to be brighter than CO 3-2.
For the peak intensity of the continuum, we took an average value of 4 mJy/beam based on the values found for HD 135344B and MWC 758.
Compared to the previous science goals, we propose to observe at larger angular resolution (0.35 arcsec) to better characterize the largest structures already known in this source.
The mid-frequency of the continuum range was chosen to avoid the slight dips in atmospheric transmission at 231.3GHz and 234 GHz.
Although we do not need a spectral resolution of 61kHz for our science goal, we do not have other choice if we want to observe at the same time CO 2-1 and 13CO 2-1 transitions in view of the separation of 10.14GHz between both lines. Choosing a spectral resolution of 122 kHz or larger (234 MHz width) would imply the lines to overtake the limit of the basebands. We will then average channels to obtain bins of 0.2 km/s width, hence increasing the SNR. This resolution was sufficient to detect the three spiral arms in HD 142527.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Spiral patterns have been observed in near-IR (NIR) scattered light in a few transition disks. Recently, ALMA cycle 0 observations allowed us to discover spiral arms in CO gas in the outer disk of HD 142527. We propose to extend our results of HD 142527 to three other transition disks with evidence for NIR spiral features. We will seek to determine whether these spiral structures are also present in the gas, and if larger structures can be detected like the ones of HD 142527. The latter were best seen in ALMA band 6 12CO J=2-1 line as they are very cold (T <~ 20 K). Simultaneously, we will also measure the large dust distribution in the disk, and compute CO opacity and gas mass inside and outside the gaps with the 13CO isotopologue. The characterization of the dynamics of the gas and large dust in such spiral features, along with the quality of their fit to the current physical frameworks assuming the presence of a planet, and estimates of Toomre parameter, will allow us to put new constraints on their origin (e.g. planet, gravitational instability, or other).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 'Gas kinematics inside large protoplanetary cavities' (PI Casassus, project code: 2013.1.01084.S);
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
